The idea is pretty simple, news sites want Google to index their content so it shows up in search results. So they don't show a paywall to the Google crawler. We benefit from this because the Google crawler will cache a copy of the site every time it crawls it.

This site shows you that cached, unpaywalled version of the page.

https://12ft.io/

Because of reasons (see https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.3000356 ) we decided to try to disassemble the communities —i.e. isolate each member species from a community and then rebuild the community with fixed initial population sizes— between rounds of selection.

This allows us to change the species composition and explore the landscape of different communities. As an effect, we can find communities that degrade better than the initial ones, i.e. we can actually IMPROVE the max function.

title: Geometric local systems on very general curves and isomonodromy

last_post.content:
It's cool to see other peoples' exposition of one's work -- there's an ongoing seminar at Humboldt on 2 of my papers with Landesman (https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.00039 and https://arxiv.org/abs/2205.15352). They just finished the first paper, and notes are posted here: https://notnotraju.github.io/LL.html

One of the coolest things about this is seeing how their exposition differs from ours -- it's really nice to see slightly different points of view on the same results!

You can filter any Mastodon account's public posts by hashtag using the following website address:

(mastodon profile's web address)/tagged/(hashtag without the #)

So, for example, to see all my public posts with the hashtag "Mastodon" the address would be:

https://mstdn.social/@feditips/tagged/mastodon

:rss: As many have pointed out in comments, you can also add .rss to the end of the address to create an RSS feed.
